name: cardinalis-cardinalis
definition: A North American bird having a crested head, a short thick bill, and bright red plumage in the male.
description:
The northern cardinal is a mid-sized songbird with a body length of 21 to 23.5 centimeters and a wingspan of 25 to 31 centimeters.

The adult weighs from 33.6 to 65 grams. The male averages slightly larger than the female.

The adult male is a brilliant crimson red color with a black face mask over the eyes, extending to the upper chest.

The color becomes duller and darker on the back and wings.

The female is fawn, with mostly grayish-brown tones and a slight reddish tint on the wings, the crest, and the tail feathers.

Northern cardinals natural habitat is in woodlands, gardens, shrublands, and wetlands.

The diet of the northern cardinal consists mainly of weed seeds, grains, and fruits.

It is a ground feeder and finds food while hopping on the ground through trees or shrubbery.

It will also consume insects, including beetles, cicadas, grasshoppers, and snails; it feeds its young almost exclusively on insects.

Other common items include corn and oats, sunflower seeds, the blossoms and bark of elm trees, and maple sap from holes made by sapsuckers.

During the summer months it shows preference for seeds that are easily husked, but is less selective when food is scarce during winter.

Putting safflower seed in a feeder is an effective strategy for attracting them.

This diet adaptability helps the birds stay in their same area year-round.

Northern cardinals mate for life, and the pair stay together throughout the year.

The female builds a cup shaped nest, in a well concealed spot from a dense shrub or a small tree, at 1 to 3 meters above the ground.

The nest is made of thin twigs, bark strips, and grasses, lined with grasses or other plant fibers.

Eggs are laid one to six days following the completion of the nest.

The female generally incubates the eggs and incubation takes 12 to 13 days. Young fledge 10 to 11 days after hatching.

Northern cardinals can be aggressive birds that violently defend their territories, and males will chase away competitors.

Cardinals will also attack their reflections in mirrors, windows, chrome bumpers, and other reflective surfaces, often spending hours attacking what they perceive as unwelcome intruders.

Because of their beauty, dedication to mates and musical songs, cardinals are one of the most popular species among birders and non-birders alike.

Northern cardinals are preyed upon by a wide variety of predators native to North America.

These include falcons, all Accipiter hawks, shrikes, bald eagles, golden eagles and several owls, including long-eared owls, and eastern screech owls.

Predators of chicks and eggs include milk snakes, coluber constrictors, blue jays, eastern gray squirrels, fox squirrels, eastern chipmunks, and domestic cats.

featured.caption:
Cardinals are dimorphic birds, and while the red males are instantly recognizable, the more camouflaged females are also lovely and elegant.

Female cardinals are a soft, warm tan color with a bright orange bill and red edging to the wings and tail.

facts.name: Males are able to incorporate pigments
facts.value: Males are able to incorporate pigments (called carotenoids) from the food they eat into their plumage in order to produce and maintain red color of the feathers.

facts.name: Males are very noisy
facts.value: Males produce loud, chipping noise when they detect predators near the nest. Same sound is used when bird wants to find its partner during the periods of poor visibility.

facts.name: Males can sing up to 200 songs per hour
facts.value: Males can sing up to 200 songs per hour. Songs are often composed of series of whistles. Their goal is to deter competing males from the occupied territory.

facts.name: Is an omnivore bird
facts.value: Northern cardinal is an omnivore (it eats plants and meat). 90% of diet is based on seed and fruit. Beetles, grasshoppers, ants, flies, dragonflies and many other types of insects are the primary source of food for the young birds.

facts.name: Predators
facts.value: Cats, squirrels, raccoons, skunks and snakes target eggs of northern cardinal, while owls, falcons and hawks hunt adult birds.

facts.name: Strong, cone-shaped beak
facts.value: Northern cardinal has strong, cone-shaped beak, crest on top of a head and long tail. Bird erects its crest when it senses danger.

facts.name: Determine gender by color
facts.value: Gender of the northern cardinal can be determined via coloration of the body. Males have black face and bright red-colored body. Females are covered with grayish-brown plumage and have grey face.

facts.name: Gregarious bird living in large flocks
facts.value: Northern cardinal is gregarious bird that lives in large flocks outside the breeding season.

facts.name: Can reach 23.5 centimeters in length
facts.value: Northern cardinal can reach 21 to 23.5 centimeters in length and 33.6 to 65 grams of weight.

facts.name: Cardinals of the Catholic Church
facts.value: Name "cardinal" refers to the cardinals of the Catholic Church which wear red vestments.

facts.name: Female builds the nest
facts.value: Female builds nest in the tree or bush and lays 3 eggs. She often sings from the nest. Incubation period lasts 12 to 13 days. Both parents provide food for chicks. Young birds leave the nest 10 to 11 days after hatching.

facts.name: Can survive up to 15 years in the wild
facts.value: Northern cardinal can survive up to 15 years in the wild and up to 28 years in the captivity.

facts.name: Searches food at dusk and dawn
facts.value: Northern cardinal searches food at dusk and dawn (crepuscular birds).

facts.name: Form monogamous pairs
facts.value: Northern cardinals form monogamous pairs (they mate for a lifetime) and produce 2 to 4 broods per year.Northern cardinal is territorial during the mating season. Male will attack its own reflection in the mirror to protect territory from the "intruder". Male also provides food for the female during the period of incubation.
